content.explanation: Primitive types are passed by value. The doublevalues method receives copies of a and b. It prints 20 and 10, then returns. The original variables a=10, b=5 are unchanged, so trial() prints 5 and 10. Total output: 2010510.

common_mistakes.misconception: Student only traces the method call output

options.text: The sum of all the integers greater than y but less than or equal to x
The sum of all the integers greater than or equal to y but less than or equal to x
The sum of all the integers greater than y but less than x
The sum of all the integers greater than y but less than or equal to x
The sum of all the integers less than y but greater than or equal to x

content.explanation: Loop: c starts at a (x), continues while c > b (y), decrements. Sums a + (a-1) + ... + (b+1). This is all integers greater than y but ≤ x.

mystery(3): k=0 calls mystery(0) (prints nothing), prints 3; k=1 calls mystery(1) (prints 1), prints 3; k=2 calls mystery(2) (prints 10 + 2=012), prints 3. Total: 00 + 1 + 00 + 1 + 0 + 0 + 1 + 2 + 3 = 00100123.

content.text: Consider an array of integers: [4, 10, 1, 2, 6, 7, 3, 5]. If selection sort is used to order the array from smallest to largest values, which of the following represents a possible state of the array at some point during the selection sort process?
content.explanation: Selection sort finds the minimum of unsorted portion and swaps to front. After 3 passes: sorted portion [1,2,3], unsorted [10,6,7,4,5] remains in original order. Only option C matches this pattern.

common_mistakes.misconception: Too much sorting in unsorted portion

content.explanation: First loop: A[k] = 7-k creates [7,6,5,4,3,2,1]. Second loop: A[k+1] = A[k] cascades the first value (7) through the array. Result: [7,7,7,7,7,7,7].
Arrays are 0-indexed. 10th office = p[9], 57th box = getBox(56), 4th piece = getMail(3). Correct: p[9].getBox(56).getMail(3).
Loops use k for post offices and x for boxes. Correct condition: p[k].getBox(x).isAssigned() && !p[k].getBox(x).hasMail(). Correct print: p[k].getBox(x).getBoxNumber().

content.text:
Assume that a and b are Boolean variables that have been initialized. Consider the following code segment. 

`a = a && b; b = a || b;`

 Which of the following statements is true?

options.text: I only (The final value of a is the same as the initial value of a.)
II only (The final value of b is the same as the initial value of b.)
III only (The final value of a is the same as the initial value of b.)

content.explanation: Analysis: (1) a_new = a_old && b_old (not always equal to a_old). (2) b_new = (a_old && b_old) || b_old = b_old (absorption law - always true). (3) a_new ≠ b_old unless special conditions. Only II is always true.
x=53: First if (53>10) prints A; Second if (53>30) prints B, else-if skipped; Third if (53>50) prints D; Fourth if (53>70) false, no print. Output: ABD.

mystery(5): 5%3=2 prints X; mystery(4): 4%3=1 prints X-X; mystery(3): 3%3=0 prints X--X; mystery(2): 2%3=2 prints X; mystery(1): 1%3=1 prints X-X. Output: X X-X X--X X X-X formatted as XX - XX - - XXX - X.

content.text: What is the correct way to define the signature of the constructor for the DiningRoomSet class?

options.text: public void DiningRoomSet (Table t, ArrayList, chairs)
public void DiningRoomSet (Table t, ArrayList Chair Chairs)
public DiningRoomSet (Table t, ArrayList Chair Chairs)

content.explanation: Constructor should: (1) NOT have void, (2) have correct class name, (3) have properly generic ArrayList<Chair>. Option B is closest valid syntax, though technically should be ArrayList<Chair>.

common_mistakes.misconception: ArrayList type parameter in wrong place

options.text: public double getPrice(Table t, ArrayList chairs) { return t.getPrice() + chairs.getPrice() ; }
public double getPrice(Table t, ArrayList chairs) { return myTable.getPrice() + myChairs.getPrice(); }
public double getPrice() { return myTable.getPrice() + myChairs.getPrice(); }
public double getPrice() { double result = myTable.getPrice(); for (int k = 0; k < myChairs.size() - 1; k++) { result += ((Chair)myChairs.get(k)).getPrice(); } return result; }
public double getPrice() { double result = myTable.getPrice() ; for (int k = 0; k < myChairs.size(); k++) { result += ((Chair)myChairs.get(k)).getPrice( ); } return result ; }

content.explanation: Must iterate through ALL chairs (k < myChairs.size(), not size()-1). Option D has off-by-one error. Option E correctly sums table + all chairs.

content.text:
Consider the following output:
6 5 4 3 2 1
5 4 3 2 1
4 3 2 1
3 2 1
2 1
1
Which of the following code segments produces the above output?

options.text: for (int j = 6; j < 0; j--) { for (int k = j; k > 0 ; k --) { System.out.print (k + " ") ; } System.out.println("") ; }
for (int j = 6; j >= 0; j--) { for (int k = j; k >= 0; k--) { System.out.print(k + " "); } System.out.println (" ") ; }
for (int j = 0; j < 6; j++) { for (int k = 6 - j; k > 0; k--) { System.out.print (k + " ") ; } system.out.println (" ") ; }
for (int j = 0; j < 6; j++) { for (int k = 7 - j ; k > 0 ; k --) { System.out.print(k + " "); } System.out.println (" ") ; }
for (int j = 0; j < 6; j++) { for (int k = 6 - j ; k >= 0; k--) { System.out.print(k + " "); } System.out.println (" ") ; }

content.explanation: Pattern: iterate j from 0 to 5; each row starts at 6-j and counts down to 1. Outer: j 0-5; Inner: k from (6-j) down to 1 (k > 0).
Interface requires both makeSound() and animalType(). Dog has makeSound(Animal a) which is different signature. Must implement both interface methods: makeSound() and animalType().

Instance variables are NOT polymorphic - use declared type (Fish). Methods ARE polymorphic - use runtime type (Shark). Result: endoskeleton="bone" (Fish), action() calls Shark version prints "chomp chomp".
Must shift element right: sort[index]=sort[index-1], and move left: index--. This creates space for smaller elements.

content.text: Assuming that the missing code is implemented properly, what change can be made to the code in order for the array to be sorted in descending order?
content.explanation: To reverse sort order, reverse the comparison: > becomes <. Rest of logic remains same. Change sort[index-1]>temp to sort[index-1]<temp.

content.text: Which of the following arrays would be sorted the slowest using insertion sort?
content.explanation: Insertion sort worst case is when array is in reverse order (every element must be compared with all previous). [9,7,6,5,4,3,2] is reverse sorted, requiring maximum comparisons.

content.text: Consider the method multiply of the Fraction class. Which of the following statements can be used to replace the missing code?
content.explanation: Must: (1) use 'new', (2) use public getter methods not private fields, (3) properly call getDenominator(). Option III is correct.
Instance method syntax: object.method(parameter). answer = fractionOne.multiply(fractionTwo);

content.text: Consider the proposed constructors for the ReducedFraction class. Which of these constructor(s) would be legal?
content.explanation: Constructor I: Legal, initializes only reduced fields. Constructor II: Illegal - lowercase 'reducedFraction' wrong, directly accesses private fields. Constructor III: Legal - calls super() properly, initializes reduced fields.

content.text: Consider s1 and s2 defined as follows. String s1 = new String("hello"); String s2 = new String("hello"); Which of the following is/are correct ways to see if s1 and s2 hold identical strings?

options.text: II and III only: if (s1.compareTo(s2) == 0) AND if (s1.equals(s2))

content.explanation: == checks references (different objects, so false). compareTo()==0 checks content (true). equals() checks content (true). II and III are correct.
Strings are passed by value. Inside mystery, parameters a and b change, but original s and t are unchanged. Answer: s=Elizabeth, t=Andrew.
I. FALSE - objects in same class CAN access private fields. II. TRUE - Comparable requires Object parameter. III. TRUE - Comparable requires int return type, not boolean.

content.text: Consider the following abstraction of a for loop. Which of the following while loops has the same functionality?
content.explanation: For loop: init <1>, check <2>, exec <4>, then increment <3>. While: init <1>, check <2>, exec <4>, then increment <3>. Body comes before increment.

content.text: Consider the following expression: a / b + c – d % e * f Which of the expressions given below is equivalent?
content.explanation: Precedence: /, %, * (left to right) > +, - (left to right). Expression = (a/b) + c - ((d%e)*f).

content.text: Assume that a program declares and initializes x as follows: String [] x; x = new String[10]; initialize(x); // Fills the array x with valid strings each of length 5. Which of the following code segments correctly traverses the array and prints out the first character of all ten strings followed by the second character of all ten strings?
content.explanation: Want character index (0-4) as outer loop, string index (0-9) as inner loop. II: for(i=0; i<5; i++) for(j=0; j<10; j++) x[j].substring(i,i+1) - Correct. I and III have wrong loop order.
a and b are integers, so a/b = 7/4 = 1 (integer division). Then 1 is assigned to c, giving 1.0.

options.text: Whenever x is even and x is not divisible by 3
Whenever x is odd and x is divisible by 3
Whenever x is even and x is divisible by 3

content.explanation: x%2==0: x is even. x/3==1: x in [3,5] (integer division). Both: x in [3,5] AND even = x==4.

content.text: Now consider the method swap. Which of the following code segments can replace the missing code so the method works as intended?

options.text: I only: SomeClass temp; temp = x; x = y; y = temp;
III only: String temp; temp = x.getName(); x.setName(y.getName()); y.setName(temp);

content.explanation: Must swap the NAME values, not the objects. Option III calls setName/getName correctly. Option I swaps object references (doesn't swap names). Option II accesses private fields directly.

content.text: A bookstore wants to store information about books with different types. Which of the following is the best design?

options.text: One class Book with data fields

content.explanation: Best OOP design uses inheritance hierarchy matching the data structure: Book has two main branches (Fiction/NonFiction), each with 3 sub-types. Option E shows proper abstraction and hierarchy.
Trace with return value 2: mystery(1)=2, mystery(2)=2*2+2=6, mystery(3)=2*6+3=15, mystery(4)=2*15+4=34. ✓
Loop exits when: k >= X.length OR X[k] != Y[k]. By De Morgan's law, this is the negation of the loop condition. Answer: k >= X.length || X[k] != Y[k].

content.text: Which of the following would NOT cause a run-time exception?

options.text: Using an object that has been declared but not instantiated
Accessing an array element with index == array length
Attempting to cast an object to a subclass of which it is not an instance
Attempting to call a method with wrong number of arguments

content.explanation: (A-D) cause ArithmeticException, NullPointerException, ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, ClassCastException respectively. (E) is a compile-time error, not runtime.

common_mistakes.misconception: No exception for division by zero

content.text:
Assume that a and b are properly initialized variables of type Double. Which of the following is equivalent to: 

`a.doubleValue() != b.doubleValue()`?
content.explanation: != checks if values are different. compareTo(b) returns 0 if equal, nonzero if different. a.compareTo(b) != 0 is equivalent.

content.text: Which of the following would be the LEAST effective way of ensuring reliability in a program?
content.explanation: Making data public violates encapsulation, the fundamental principle for reliability. All other options actively improve reliability.

content.text: Consider a dictionary that has 1,000 pages with 50 words on each page. In order to look up a given target word, a student is considering using one of the following three methods. Which of the following best characterizes the greatest number of words that will be examined using each method?
content.explanation: Method 1: Binary search pages (log₂1000≈10) + linear on page (50) ≈ 60. Method 2: Linear pages (1000) + linear on page (50) ≈ 1050. Method 3: Linear all (50000).

content.text: Which of the following is NOT a peripheral?
content.explanation: Peripherals are external hardware devices. A word processing application is software, not hardware, so not a peripheral.
